column4: You can get the output of commands directly  into vim with ":r!<command>
Cool, but that wasn't really going to help me was I was trying to do, but it's fine now I did it the long way. lol
How good are you with vim? I kind of like but I have another question. lol
What's the question?
I am using visual mode to copy and paste, any way I can paste in to a new line without hitting o and then pushing esc to get out of inserting text? lol Just to remove 1 step.
Paste from the clipboard or 'put' from the buffer?
buffer. Sorry. lol Still new.
I am not sure what you mean then, you wouldn't be in insert mode after a put ( I am probably misinterpreting what you asked )
Well, I am after I hit 'o' to open a new line, than I have to esc again and then use put. I was asking any way I can do that without going into insert mode when putting into a new line.
lowercase 'p' should paste on a new line by default, are you using capital 'P' ?
No, it actually puts where my cursor is.
That is odd, I just tried it and it puts on a new line for me, you don't have caps lock on?
No.
I mean I am sure, it's not on.lol
What does capital 'P' do for you?
I don't see a difference. lol
Ahh, my mistake, I usually put after doing a 'yy' and that puts a newline in the buffer :)
Ah, so It's 'yy' and than 'p'? It works that way, Thanks.
np
In case you don't know, 'yy' will yank ( copy ) the entire line
Okay. :)
What issue are you having?

When I navigate to a long directory, that filles the width of the prompt, and I type a command or something, when I backspace the cursor jumps a line up and when I start typing it again the lines repeat.
